statement.tex:
%text Find the relationship between $\alpha$ and $\beta$ so that the function 'f' defined by % f(x) = \begin{cases} \alpha x + 1, \text{ if }x\leq 3 \\ \beta x + 3, \text{ if } x \gt 3 \end{cases} \\ %text
is continuous at $x=3$ %
\\ %text For f(x) to be continuous at $x=3$, \underline\text{what conditions must be satisfied}? %
\\ %text Given the conditions for continuity, which of following correctly shows the \underline\text{limits} \underline\text{and values} for the function \underline\text{at $x=3$}? %
\\ %text Given the limits and values for the function at $x=3$, can we conclude / infer the following \underline\text{about $\alpha$ and $\beta$}? %

reason.tex:
%text For a function to be continuous at $x=a$, \underline\text{the following conditions} must be satisfied
(i) f(a) must exist / be defined. (ii) $\lim_{x\to a}f(x)$ must exist. In other words, $\lim_{x\to a^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+}f(x)
(iii) And, $\lim_{x\to a}f(x) = f(a)$.
If all three conditions are satisfied, then the function can be \underline\text{drawn at, and around,} \underline\text{$x=a$ without lifting the pencil}. %

%text Bear in mind the \underline\text{definition of the function} that we were given. % f(x) = \begin{cases} \alpha x + 1, \text{ if }x\leq 3 \\ \beta x + 3, \text{ if } x \gt 3 \end{cases} \\ %text
And therefore, % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Meaning} & \text{Value} \\ \hline \lim_{x\to 3^-}f(x) & \text{Left-hand limit} & 3\alpha + 1 \\ \hline \lim_{x\to 3^+}f(x) & \text{Right-hand limit} & 3\beta + 3 \\ \hline f(3) & \text{Function's value} & 3\alpha + 1 \\ \hline \end{tabular}
